00028 /*
00029  * This file is part of Lustre, http://www.lustre.org/
00030  * Lustre is a trademark of Sun Microsystems, Inc.
00031  *
00032  * libcfs/include/libcfs/libcfs_cpu.h
00033  *
00034  * CPU partition
00035  *   . CPU partition is virtual processing unit
00036  *
00037  *   . CPU partition can present 1-N cores, or 1-N NUMA nodes,
00038  *     in other words, CPU partition is a processors pool.
00039  *
00040  * CPU Partition Table (CPT)
00041  *   . a set of CPU partitions
00042  *
00043  *   . There are two modes for CPT: CFS_CPU_MODE_NUMA and CFS_CPU_MODE_SMP
00044  *
00045  *   . User can specify total number of CPU partitions while creating a
00046  *     CPT, ID of CPU partition is always start from 0.
00047  *
00048  *     Example: if there are 8 cores on the system, while creating a CPT
00049  *     with cpu_npartitions=4:
00050  *              core[0, 1] = partition[0], core[2, 3] = partition[1]
00051  *              core[4, 5] = partition[2], core[6, 7] = partition[3]
00052  *
00053  *          cpu_npartitions=1:
00054  *              core[0, 1, ... 7] = partition[0]
00055  *
00056  *   . User can also specify CPU partitions by string pattern
00057  *
00058  *     Examples: cpu_partitions="0[0,1], 1[2,3]"
00059  *               cpu_partitions="N 0[0-3], 1[4-8]"
00060  *
00061  *     The first character "N" means following numbers are numa ID
00062  *
00063  *   . NUMA allocators, CPU affinity threads are built over CPU partitions,
00064  *     instead of HW CPUs or HW nodes.
00065  *
00066  *   . By default, Lustre modules should refer to the global cfs_cpt_table,
00067  *     instead of accessing HW CPUs directly, so concurrency of Lustre can be
00068  *     configured by cpu_npartitions of the global cfs_cpt_table
00069  *
00070  *   . If cpu_npartitions=1(all CPUs in one pool), lustre should work the
00071  *     same way as 2.2 or earlier versions
00072  *
00073  * Author: liang@whamcloud.com
00074  */
00075

00081 struct cfs_cpt_table {
00082         /* # of CPU partitions */
00083         int                     ctb_nparts;
00084         /* cpu mask */
00085         cpumask_t               ctb_mask;
00086         /* node mask */
00087         nodemask_t              ctb_nodemask;
00088         /* version */
00089         __u64                   ctb_version;
00090 };
00091 
00092 #endif /* !HAVE_LIBCFS_CPT */
00093 
00094 /* any CPU partition */
00095 #define CFS_CPT_ANY             (-1)
00096

00200 /*
00201  * allocate per-cpu-partition data, returned value is an array of pointers,
00202  * variable can be indexed by CPU ID.
00203  *      cptab != NULL: size of array is number of CPU partitions
00204  *      cptab == NULL: size of array is number of HW cores
00205  */
00206 void *cfs_percpt_alloc(struct cfs_cpt_table *cptab, unsigned int size);
00207 /*
00208  * destory per-cpu-partition variable
00209  */
00210 void  cfs_percpt_free(void *vars);
00211 int   cfs_percpt_number(void *vars);
00212 
00213 #define cfs_percpt_for_each(var, i, vars)               \
00214         for (i = 0; i < cfs_percpt_number(vars) &&      \
00215                 ((var) = (vars)[i]) != NULL; i++)
00216 
00217 /*
00218  * percpu partition lock
00219  *
00220  * There are some use-cases like this in Lustre:
00221  * . each CPU partition has it's own private data which is frequently changed,
00222  *   and mostly by the local CPU partition.
00223  * . all CPU partitions share some global data, these data are rarely changed.
00224  *
00225  * LNet is typical example.
00226  * CPU partition lock is designed for this kind of use-cases:
00227  * . each CPU partition has it's own private lock
00228  * . change on private data just needs to take the private lock
00229  * . read on shared data just needs to take _any_ of private locks
00230  * . change on shared data needs to take _all_ private locks,
00231  *   which is slow and should be really rare.
00232  */
00233 enum {
00234         CFS_PERCPT_LOCK_EX      = -1,   /* negative */
00235 };
00236 
00237 struct cfs_percpt_lock {
00238         /* cpu-partition-table for this lock */
00239         struct cfs_cpt_table     *pcl_cptab;
00240         /* exclusively locked */
00241         unsigned int              pcl_locked;
00242         /* private lock table */
00243         spinlock_t              **pcl_locks;
00244 };
00245 
00246 /* return number of private locks */
00247 #define cfs_percpt_lock_num(pcl)        cfs_cpt_number(pcl->pcl_cptab)
00248 
00249 /*
00250  * create a cpu-partition lock based on CPU partition table \a cptab,
00251  * each private lock has extra \a psize bytes padding data
00252  */
00253 struct cfs_percpt_lock *cfs_percpt_lock_create(struct cfs_cpt_table *cptab,
00254                                                struct lock_class_key *keys);
00255 /* destroy a cpu-partition lock */
00256 void cfs_percpt_lock_free(struct cfs_percpt_lock *pcl);
00257 
00258 /* lock private lock \a index of \a pcl */
00259 void cfs_percpt_lock(struct cfs_percpt_lock *pcl, int index);
00260 /* unlock private lock \a index of \a pcl */
00261 void cfs_percpt_unlock(struct cfs_percpt_lock *pcl, int index);
00262 
00263 #define CFS_PERCPT_LOCK_KEYS   256
00264 
00265 /* NB: don't allocate keys dynamically, lockdep needs them to be in ".data" */
00266 #define cfs_percpt_lock_alloc(cptab)                                    \
00267 ({                                                                      \
00268         static struct lock_class_key  ___keys[CFS_PERCPT_LOCK_KEYS];    \
00269         struct cfs_percpt_lock       *___lk;                            \
00270                                                                         \
00271         if (cfs_cpt_number(cptab) > CFS_PERCPT_LOCK_KEYS)               \
00272                 ___lk = cfs_percpt_lock_create(cptab, NULL);            \
00273         else                                                            \
00274                 ___lk = cfs_percpt_lock_create(cptab, ___keys);         \
00275         ___lk;                                                          \
00276 })
00277 
00284 static inline void *
00285 cfs_cpt_malloc(struct cfs_cpt_table *cptab, int cpt, size_t nr_bytes,
00286                gfp_t flags)
00287 {
00288         return kmalloc_node(nr_bytes, flags,
00289                             cfs_cpt_spread_node(cptab, cpt));
00290 }
00291 
00296 static inline void *
00297 cfs_cpt_vzalloc(struct cfs_cpt_table *cptab, int cpt, size_t nr_bytes)
00298 {
00299         /* vzalloc_node() sets __GFP_FS by default but no current Kernel
00300          * exported entry-point allows for both a NUMA node specification
00301          * and a custom allocation flags mask. This may be an issue since
00302          * __GFP_FS usage can cause some deadlock situations in our code,
00303          * like when memory reclaim started, within the same context of a
00304          * thread doing FS operations, that can also attempt conflicting FS
00305          * operations, ...
00306          */
00307         return vzalloc_node(nr_bytes, cfs_cpt_spread_node(cptab, cpt));
00308 }
00309 
00314 static inline struct page *
00315 cfs_page_cpt_alloc(struct cfs_cpt_table *cptab, int cpt, gfp_t flags)
00316 {
00317         return alloc_pages_node(cfs_cpt_spread_node(cptab, cpt), flags, 0);
00318 }
00319 
00324 static inline void *
00325 cfs_mem_cache_cpt_alloc(struct kmem_cache *cachep, struct cfs_cpt_table *cptab,
00326                         int cpt, gfp_t flags)
00327 {
00328         return kmem_cache_alloc_node(cachep, flags,
00329                                      cfs_cpt_spread_node(cptab, cpt));
00330 }

00336         for (i = 0; i < cfs_cpt_number(cptab); i++)
